title: Sri Lanka stock indices plunge over 5% soon after market opens
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stock market trading was halted just one minute after the trading opened on Tuesday as the both key indices fell over 5 percent amid concerns over a 7 percent rate hike, the country suspending repayment of foreign debts, and sovereign credit rating downgrade.
The ASPI was 416.21 points down at 7,097.64 as soon as the market opened.
Most liquid index S&P SL20 also fell over 5.47 percent at the first minute after market started trading.
Trading was halted and the Colombo Stock Exchange said trading will resume at 11.01 am.

The Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) was forced to close the market with less than five minutes of trading on Monday after it opened trading following a two week break. The CSE closed the market citing investors need a cooling off period. Some investors have told Economy Next that they were not in favour of the decision.
The stock exchange has circuit breakers at 5.0 percent, 7.5 percent and 10.00 percent after which the market is closed. (Colombo/April26/2022)
